content:
Yes, there are several modern-day indigenous communities who still practice hunting and gathering techniques similar to those used by the Thule people. 

One example is the Inuit people, who are indigenous to the Arctic regions of Canada, Alaska, and Greenland. They continue to rely on hunting and gathering for food, and hunt marine mammals such as seals, whales, and walruses with traditional tools such as harpoons and knives. They also rely on fishing, trapping, and gathering berries and other plants. 

Another example is the Sami people, who are indigenous to the northern parts of Scandinavia, Russia, and Finland. They practice reindeer herding and fishing, utilizing traditional techniques and tools to navigate their harsh, snowy environment. 

While these communities have adapted to modern technologies and ways of life to various degrees, they continue to maintain important aspects of their traditional cultures and ways of living - incorporating them into their modern lifestyles.
